comments.commentBody:
The comment from Eric Schmidt is referring to the fact that by serving ads of their businesses the businesses make money off of google's ad distribution network and serving platform.
So your example of telephone/electricity would be more apt if business were straight up making a product using electricity sourced by a provider or providing a telephone based service riding on top of telephone networks built by the network operators.

The United States should advance a policy of negotiations forwarding the notion of peace at all times  with great perseverance,,,,but it should be anchored by a clear UN declaration of a policy of total war. That is to say, the morbid and inane policy of "limited warfare" and "police actions" fostered post WWll would be replaced by a constitutional War Powers Act national vote,,once the United States, as a nation, is forced to enter an arena of war, the absolute power of the United States armed forces would be used.  In turn there would be no obtuse nation building, or rebuilding,,,, and the populations of waring nations would clearly know  the consequences of a war with the United States and be fully accountable for their failure to garner peace.

whew. what a relief to know that a member of the Royal Family is willing to step in and take over the news dept. when one of their employees is caught collaborating with a foreign government in their reporting.
never happen here. except, of course, the experts used by all our networks on the iraqi war who were granted access by the pentagon based on reporting only what the pentagon told them to say. Though, i can't recall if our Bush II stepped in and replaced any of these guys, or even if anyone told him about it.
I suspected Al Jazeera was playing it down under US pressure.  Anyone who followed that network saw the change in coverage.

Good description of the difficulties in coming up with a reasonable estimate. I'm no statistician, but whether the total was 620K or 850K, the total was quite awesome...

H
H
H

Fascinating article, I'd always taken the 600,000 deaths number to be written in stone. It also puts me in mind of another possible issue I've never seen discussed. Anytime historians mention Sherman's march to the sea, the damage they did is nearly always cited as a dollar amount, in the general neighborhood of hundreds of millions of dollars. This is rarely if ever broken down, however, and what I'd like to know is what percentage of that "damage" done to the southern economy is actually the black southern population leaving the plantations and their "owners," thereby taking themselves off the ledger books of the planters. I've a suspicion that the majority of the so-called damage done by Sherman and his bummers is actually the freeing of the slaves, and not the burning of barns and crops and the stealing of silverware, but mentiong this fact would be embarrassing to the historians determined to take the moral high ground against Sherman's successful strategy.
The total count of Civil War deaths is still too low. We should have hanged a few hundred thousand rebs after the War, starting with Bobby Lee and Jeff Davis.

But was it worth it? I think that is the most important question to ask. Was that war--which freed the slaves and re-united the nation--worth the destruction of large swaths of territory and 750,000 lives?

Unfortunately there is too much on my plate and the world's plate to comment on the prospect of beginning being to boycott tuna now.

There is a limited amount of time and resources to deal with all the things in the world that need amelioration.

At least, I'm concise.
Thank you for the informative editorial.      Sign me up!

Mr Brooks,
You may be a "sap", but please don't assume your readers are stupid enough to believe you've ever been an Obama supporter. Your occasional praise for the president is most often used as a lead in for a back hand. As for "half truths", your cooked CBO income versus income taxes paid statistics don't even begin to hold water when taxes paid versus actual gross income is taken into account. The thing that's really tiring about your pieces is your constant assumption that your readers are that gullible.

David, If you had spent at least half the article talking about the intransigence of the Republicans and their irresponsible, destructive approach to governance in this era of polarization, I could take the rest of your whiny, self-pitying blather. Instead you give it a short, dismissive mention -- so no one can say you let them off the hook -- and then repeat the "I'm a sap" line to death.

You are a sap sir, but not in the way that you claim. You are a sap because you spend a career soft-selling the evermore malevolent intent of your own party while being snarky or outraged when the other side gives back 50% in-kind, occasionally. You ARE the embodiment of the false equivalence argument and what's most amazing is that you can deliver it with a straight, even indignant face. Sad sappy shame, you.
"Back to politics as usual?"  You mean back to forcing the GOP to consider the average American as part of their constituency.  Brooks, you might as well stop selling it, because no one is buying it.

When at the Republican debate the candidates were asked to show hand if they would accept a 10 to 1 budget cuts to tax increase deal and none of them raised there hands. The notion that at least the Republicans tell the truth is not the truth. They Lie.
They lie even at the very heart of their supposed beliefs when they tell you they believe in less government, but then you find them telling gay people they can't serve openly in the military, can't get married, woman can't have abortions and on and on and you realize they only believe in less government when it comes to corporations because they seem to be confused into thinking corporation are people. Billions in campaign donations from corporations will do that to you I guess.

Maybe, maybe, the important thing in all this noise, is that BO can convince the 'American People' that his 'balanced approach' is better than the republican approach.
Is this not the best strategy? If he can influence popular opinion, is this not a good thing? He did it before and I hope he can do it again.
First time I've ever agreed with you Brooks.  But you do realize that this means you are not just a sap now, but have been one for years?
Yes, you're a sap all right Mr. Brooks. But not for the reasons you give.

Mr. Brooks, you're only a sap if you believe that the current crop of Republicans in Congress would ever go along with anything -- anything -- that President Obama proposed. Unfortunately, judging from your article, it seems that you qualify under that criterion.

If politics is indeed the art of the possible, the only medium available to this president right now is one that requires contrasting images. I suspect that most Americans will appreciate his use of stark relief; that you're not among them says to me that he's doing a better job of reaching a sizable audience than he has for the last two-and-a-half years or so.

Mr. Brooks:
President Obama's Bill is supposed to get people back to work now, not months from now, correct? He is insistent that it be passed right now - calling for chants of "pass the bill" akin to "yes we can" from 2008. Disregarding whether it is "paid for" and how for a moment, what is the big jobs bill?

It's another $478B in spending on supposedly shovel ready infrastructure projects, plus some additional funding to prop up predominately union public sector jobs and the establishment of yet another bureaucracy (infrastructure bank) to dole out money to those deemed worthy of the "investment." By any other name, its a rehash of the Stimulus program, albeit on a smaller scale.

The really interesting political point is going to be whether the 23 Democrats up for re-election in the Senate will support it. If Harry Reid and his majority caucus will not back it, why would anybody expect the Republicans in the House? Hence, the really pointed answer becomes clear: if the null hypothesis is true (Dems will not support the Bill), then it must be proposed solely for political posturing. If proposed only for posturing, then who is the one playing politics?

Obama is in campaign mode, trying to rally his base & concurrently create a target & a stick with this latest "pass it now" charade. Somebody in Chicago thinks that a Truman campaign against a "do nothing" Congress is the saving grace - tough act to sell if your own Senate won't play ball. Even Truman would have trouble selling this in today's world. So good luck with that, absent a primary challenge the hopes for damage control amongst the down ticket Democrats is dismal.

you miss the point, david.  you talk about obama's strategy like it's about him and like it's about you.  ultimately, it's about the course of the nation.  if you want to head north in an eastern gale, you have to turn hard northwest and grit your teeth.  the bush tax cuts were an abject failure for our nation, and they should not become the status quo.
David Brooks ought to just change his name to Flounder.

A lovable sap, but a sap. And by the way, entitlement reform is part of the program. How did you miss that. Oh yes, the whole thing is a non starter so why not.
What you can not seem to wrap your arms around is the opposition party's agenda to damage the country so as to defeat the president.
That is not being a sap. It is blindness.

Well, David, I guess we're both saps. After years of witnessing your mindless cheerleading for our two wars and tax cuts, I thought, felt, hoped I correctly sensed a push away from your ingrained Republican partisanship.  As I watched you on the talk shows, I became a sap for David Brooks, who began to acknowledge the dangers of the hugely one-sided political wars in Washington.  I was a sap when I began reading this column, anticipating there would be criticism of Obama, as well as his detractors, but that the viewpoints would honestly assess the political landscape facing the President.  I DO find fault with him I many areas, mostly for failing to keep his promise of change.  But for you ignore the rules as defined by the Republicans that Obama has to play by, and not to account for two fruitless years of attempted concilation and compromise, and then to blast him for suddenly playing politics ... What do you think has been going on these last almost-three years?  And this line about how the wealthiest pay the greatest percentage of taxes?  In aggregate, yes.  Individidually, no, a fact you conveniently seem to ignore.  So, I was a sap for David Brooks.  And now, I am just sapped out.

But Mr. Brooks, after 2.5 years he got nowhere with trying to compromise with the other party with centrist solutions. Not only did that not work, he alienated the allies on top of that. Why shouldn't he now go with what the base wants in the first place? At least this can be a starting point for negotiations that would be fairer.

I am also a centrist compromiser but it looks like that would only work with a congress we had 20+ years ago. Which liberal thought we wound be pining for Reagan right now!

I am one of those liberals that is reasonably comfortable right now (by no means rich) and I would even benefit from a republican president. But the hell they would unleash on this country would be unthinkable because of the extremism of the tea party influence. Republicans these days trip over themselves to pander to the fringe whereas the democrats try to attract the centrist independents. So you see, electing a democrat is like electing a reasonable republican of the past.

But if this country ends up electing a republican in 2012, we really would deserve the government we elect and I don't want to hear ONE complaint on these comments from the idiot progressives that stayed home cutting their nose off to spite the country's face.

Seriously, David? Obama is now just playing politics? Getting his base riled up? Where were you during the debt ceiling hostage crisis? It's as if you expect the Republican side to behave badly and exhibit no motives other than politics. Yet, when this side pushes back, you decry us for it. Our patience with your side is exhausted. We've endured two years of nothing but the most depraved politics and mischaracterizations by the Republican side. It has not done the country any good. You seriously can not blame Democrats for pushing back against the bullies.
